title: Trump moment from White House Halloween trick-or-treat event goes viral
text:
President Trump Donald John TrumpJudge schedules hearing for ex-Trump aide who refused to appear in inquiry READ: Army officer to tell investigators he twice reported concerns over Trump's Ukraine dealings Murkowski, Collins say they won't co-sponsor Graham's impeachment resolution MORE and first lady Melania Trump Melania TrumpThe Hill's 12:30 Report: Dems, former Bolton aide clash over testimony The Hill's Morning Report - Presented by Better Medicare Alliance - ISIS leader dead; Congresswoman resigns Secret Service interviewed Eminem about Trump-threatening lyrics MORE handed out pieces of candy to children at the White House's Halloween festivities on Monday, and video of the president placing candy on the head of one child dressed as a minion is going viral online.

In the brief moment, the first couple could be seen passing out chocolate candy bars to a line of young trick-or-treaters outside the White House, as is custom for the annual Halloween celebration involving the first family.

Shortly after, a child dressed as a minion, a creature from the “Despicable Me” film, approaches the couple.

ADVERTISEMENT

The costume prompts a laugh from Trump, who pats the child on the head with a candy bar before leaving it there. Melania Trump also follows suit, placing a candy bar there.

Moments later, the candy bars could be seen falling off the top of the child's costume, with an attendee picking up the chocolate and placing it in the child’s trick-or-treat bag.

The moment has been prompting viral reactions on Twitter.

I’m sorry but... did she just put candy on this kid’s head?pic.twitter.com/uM79Rdla47 — Brian Tyler Cohen (@briantylercohen) October 29, 2019

The only Halloween video I need.pic.twitter.com/SBJxhFtYRf — Kathy Zhu (@PoliticalKathy) October 29, 2019

Donald Trump really just stuck candy on top of this kid’s head and left it there and I cannot stop laughing pic.twitter.com/EJ2pUiMRqi — Ashley StClair (@stclairashley) October 29, 2019

trump is singlehandedly making halloween great again pic.twitter.com/I1FxFsRBWy — Logan Hall (@loganclarkhall) October 29, 2019

According to CNN, the White House invited children from military families and elementary schools in the region to its festivities on Monday. The first couple reportedly passed out candy for roughly 40 minutes as part the White House celebration.

Halloween celebrations at the White House date back to the Eisenhower administration in 1958. Monday marked the Trumps’ third such celebration since the president has been in office.
